Fig. 1 The XRD patterns of Mo-W-O, MoO3 and WO3 calcined at 500 °C. Fig. 2 The Raman Spectra of Mo-W-O, MoO3 and WO3 calcined at 500 °C. Fig. 3 The comparison of XPS spectrum between (a) Mo 3d orbital in the Mo-W-O-500 and in the MoO3, (b) W 4f orbital in the Mo-W-O-500 and in the WO3. Fig. 4 (a) SEM image and (b) TEM image and (c) TEM image with the inset HRTEM image of as-prepared Mo-W-O-500 sample. Fig. 5 The conversion rates of Mo-W-O-500, 0.1 wt% Pd/MoO3 catalyst [28], MoO3-500, WO3-500 and commercial Ru/Al2O3 catalyst for cyclohexene hydrogenation. Reaction conditions: temperature of 150 °C and hydrogen pressure of 3 MPa. Fig. 6 The conversion rates of Mo-W-O-500 for four cycles and the ex-situ hydrogenated Mo-W-O bronze material for cyclohexene hydrogenation. Fig. 7 The XRD pattern of Mo-W-O-500 before hydrogenation and after hydrogenation from cycle 1 to cycle 4. Fig. 8 The TPD analysis (a) and the sample photo (b) of as-prepared Mo-W-O-500 before catalytic hydrogenation reaction and after 4 cycles of hydrogenation. Fig. 9 The XPS spectrum of (a) Mo 3d before hydrogenation, (b) W 4f and 5p before hydrogenation, (c) Mo 3d after hydrogenation, (d) W 4f and 5p after hydrogenation. Facile hydrothermal synthesis of nanorod-structured Mo0.6W0.4O3 catalyst for olefin hydrogenation with high activity Pan Mei Ming Yang ⁎ Yu Bai Shunxin Fei ⁎ Yuan Dong Hansong Cheng ⁎ Sustainable Energy Laboratory, Faculty of Materials Science and Chemistry, China University of Geosciences, Wuhan 430074, PR China Sustainable Energy Laboratory Faculty of Materials Science and Chemistry China University of Geosciences Wuhan 430074 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract We report a facile hydrothermal synthesis of nanorod-structured molybdenum-tungsten oxides as an efficient catalyst for olefin hydrogenation. The catalytic activity was demonstrated through hydrogenation of cyclohexene used as a model system. The as-prepared material was confirmed as a new phase (Mo0.6W0.4O3) via a series of characterizations, instead of a simple mixture of MoO3 and WO3. The Mo0.6W0.4O3 catalyst displays excellent catalytic activity with 100% conversion of cyclohexene in 3 h, which is much higher than that of pure MoO3 and pure WO3 synthesized with the same method. It was found that hydrogen bronze (HxMo0.6W0.4O3) was formed during the hydrogenation process, and the catalytic performance was positively correlated with the hydrogen content. The obtained nanorod-structured Mo0.6W0.4O3 without loading any noble metal exhibits much higher catalytic activity than a Pd/MoO3 catalyst. The results demonstrate that the nanorod-structured molybdenum-tungsten oxide may be a strong contender for serving as an efficient hydrogenation catalyst alternative to precious metals. Keywords Hydrothermal synthesis Molybdenum-tungsten oxides Nanorod-structure Olefin hydrogenation Hydrogen bronze materials 1 Introduction Transition metal oxides have been shown to be viable catalysts alternative to transition metals due to their variable oxidation states, high surface acidity and resistance to poisoning. Hydrogen spillover phenomena have been widely observed in the form of hydrogen bronze materials in several transition metal oxides since early 1970s [1–5]. In particular, molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) and tungsten trioxide (WO3) are well-known transition metal oxides with similar physical and chemical properties. The catalytic activity has been observed individually in MoO3 and WO3 due to the formation of hydrogen molybdenum and tungsten bronzes in the hydrogenation process. The catalytic hydrogenation properties of MoO3 and WO3 were found to be highly selective and effective both experimentally and theoretically [6–8]. Various methods for preparation of a variety of hydrogen bronze materials (HBMs) (e.g. HxWO3 and HxMoO3) have developed by many research groups and the catalytic selectivity of these materials has been examined extensively [6,7,9,10]. Formation of hydrogen bronzes with vanadium [11,12], molybdenum [13,14] and tungsten [1,15] can be realized by adding a small amount of an activating precious metal (usually Pd or Pt) upon exposing these materials to hydrogen at ambient conditions. The formation of HBMs was shown to occur via a hydrogen spillover process, which can be briefly described as follows. The process is initiated upon dissociative adsorption of H2 molecules on surfaces of a transition metal catalyst, e.g. Pt, Pd or Ru. The hydrogen atoms from the metal catalyst subsequently migrate to the terminal oxygen atoms of the metal oxide and diffuse across the metal oxide surfaces or penetrate into the lattice to form HxMoO3 or HxWO3 [16–18]. The processes have been found to be energetically facile. The HBMs have been demonstrated to be efficient catalysts in hydrogenation of ethylene or acrolein [19]. Marcq et al. [20] studied hydrogenation of ethylene by hydrogen vanadium bronzes and hydrogen molybdenum bronzes. Their work showed that the amount of ethane obtained at the end of the reaction was three times higher for HxV2O5 than for HxMoO3. Hoang-Van et al. [21] investigated selective hydrogenation of acrolein and allyl alcohol with Pt/MoO3 and Pt/WO3 as catalysts. HxMoO3 and HxWO3 were formed during H2 pretreatment of the catalysts, which were found to be highly active in catalyzing the reactions. Xi et al. [19] studied the mechanisms of catalytic hydrogenation of thiophene on hydrogen tungsten bronze using density functional theory. It was found that unlike conventional transition metal catalysts for hydrogenation, on which hydrogen forms a hydride on metal surfaces upon dissociative chemisorption with charge transfer from metal to H atoms, the metal oxide withdraws electrons from hydrogen, making the hydrogen atoms essentially protonic. Their results provided a useful insight into the design of effective catalysts for hydrogenation of thiophene and its derivatives. A hydrothermal method is an efficient technique to prepare MoO3 and WO3. The majority of applications with molybdenum oxide prepared with a hydrothermal method aimed at improving electrochemical performance of Li-ion batteries as the cathode materials [22–25]. Tungsten oxide prepared with hydrothermal method was mainly used for photovoltaic [26] and gas sensing materials [27]. In a previous study [28], we focused on the hard template method to prepare MoO3 which was used as a catalyst for olefin hydrogenation. The main disadvantage of the method is that full removal of the KIT-6 template upon completion of the synthesis is very difficult. Attempt to synthesize a complex combining molybdenum oxide and tungsten oxide was made in 1986 via an ingenious synthetic route. The material can be prepared by heating MoO3 and WO3 in a sealed tube around 600 °C or through thermal decomposition of mixed ammonium metallates [29]. The product was reported to exhibit a structure that differs from a simple mixture of MoO3 and WO3 with novel properties [30]. Paraguay-Delgado et al. [31] used a hydrothermal method to synthesize a Mo-W oxide and characterized the nanostructures, but without any further catalytic applications. Hassan et al. [32] used a polymeric precursors method to prepare Mo0.5W0.5O3 and discussed the effect of the ratios of reactants to the purity of the final products. Likewise, the author has not mentioned any applications of the compounds. Sukeun Yoon [33] used a microwave-hydrothermal method to synthesize W0.4Mo0.6O3 and carbon-decorated WOx-MoO2 nanorods used as anodes for lithium ion batteries. Yuehong Song [34] used a PEG-induced aqueous method to prepare Mo/W oxide microspheres and compared the photochromic properties with that of h-MoO3 or h-WO3 crystals. Nevertheless, monophasic MoxW1-xO3 products cannot be obtained with these methods largely due to the difference in volatilities of MoO3 and WO3. In particular, we note that selective hydrogenation with a MoxW1-xO3 complex as a catalyst has rarely been reported in literature. In the present work, we report a facile hydrothermal method to synthesize a well-ordered nanorod-structured Mo0.6W0.4O3 compound that serves as a catalyst for olefin hydrogenation without adding any precious metal. The synthetic procedure includes formation of a composite containing both molybdenum and tungsten with the atomic ratio of 3:2. The as-prepared molybdenum-tungsten oxide was characterized by X-ray diffraction, Raman Spectra and Transmission electron microscope. The catalytic performance of this material was subsequently examined and cyclohexene was chosen as the reactant for hydrogenation. The nanorod-structured molybdenum-tungsten oxide catalyst was found to be more active than a Pd/MoO3 catalyst. Our study demonstrates that the nanorod-structured molybdenum-tungsten oxide may serve as an efficient catalyst alternative to precious metals for hydrogenation of molecules containing olefin species. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of nanorod-structured Mo-W oxides The Mo-W-O nanorod-structured material was synthesized using a hydrothermal method. A solution of ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate [(NH4)4Mo7O24·4H2O, AHM] and ammonium metatungstate [(NH4)10W12O41·xH2O, AMT] with the atomic ratio of Mo/W of 3:2 was mixed with a small amount of a poly (ethylene glycol) (MW: 200 g·mol−1) solution. The molar ratio of PEG to Mo was 1:3. A saturated solution of the precursor compounds AHM and AMT was prepared at room temperature and acidified to the pH around 2 using a 10 wt% of nitric acid solution. The homogeneous solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel auto clave and heated to 200 °C for 24 h. The material was then washed with deionized water and ethanol and filtered using a vacuum pump. Finally, it was dried for 6 h at 60 °C. The obtained mixture was calcined in a muffle furnace with a ramp of 1 °C·min−1 from room temperature to the target temperature and kept at this temperature for 2 h. The samples were labelled as Mo-W-O-T, in which T stands for the calcine temperature. Pure MoO3 and WO3 crystals prepared under parallel reaction parameters were utilized for comparison. All chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further purification. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction patterns of all samples were obtained using a Bruker D8 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation and nickel filter at λ = 0.15418 nm. The current and voltage applied were 40 mA and 40 kV, respectively. The specific surface areas of the samples were characterized using the Brumauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) [35] method and the pore size distribution was obtained with the Barrett-Joyner-Halanda (BJH) [36] method. The total pore volume was calculated at the relative pressure of 0.995. Raman spectroscopic measurements were conducted at room temperature on a Bruker RFS-100s spectrometer in the range of 20–1500 cm−1 with the resolution of 1 cm−1. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) analysis was carried out using an Automated Catalyst Characterization System (AutoChem 2950 HP). Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were obtained with a JEOL Ltd JEM-2100 (HR) apparatus. Nitrogen sorption experiments were done at 77 K with a Micromeritics ASAP 3020 HD88 sorption analyzer. Before the measurement, the samples were outgassed at 150 °C in vacuum for 6 h. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a VG Multilab 2000 spectrometer with Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). All the XPS data were calibrated using the binding energy of C 1 s (284.6 eV) as the standard. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation Catalytic activity was investigated via performance evaluation of cyclohexene hydrogenation, which was carried out in a 600 mL Parr autoclave batch reactor (Parr 4568) with the magnetic stirring of 600 r/min. A PTFE inner liner with the volume of 80 mL was used to contain the liquid and the catalyst to ensure good mixing. The mass ratio of the catalyst vs. cyclohexene was 1:5. 0.2 g of the catalyst and 1 g of cyclohexene were dispersed in 40 mL of hexane. Before the reaction, hydrogen was charged and then discharged three times to purge the air before the reactor was stirred and heated to the target temperature. The reaction was carried out at 150 °C and a H2 pressure of 3 MPa. The product composition analysis was conducted upon collection of a small volume of the liquid sample periodically followed by online analysis using an Agilent 7890A-5975C gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (GC-MS). In the first hour, the sampling interval was 15 min; after that, the interval was 30 min for another 1 h. For comparison, the catalytic performance of the 0.1 wt% of Pd/Mo-100 catalyst reported in ref [28] was also examined under the same conditions. In order to prepare an ex-situ hydrogenated Mo-W-O bronze material, the sample of Mo-W-O calcined at 500 °C was hydrogenated in a batch reactor at 150 °C and a H2 pressure of 3 MPa. The catalytic performance of this bronze material was also evaluated for cyclohexene hydrogenation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and Characterization To analyze the structure and composition of the prepared Mo-W oxide, we conducted similar experiments for pure MoO3 and WO3 and compare the results for these compounds here. Prior to the comparison, the XRD patterns at different calcine temperatures varying from 200 °C to 500 °C for the Mo-W oxide were obtained and the results are shown in Fig. S1. Clearly, the crystal structure of the Mo-W oxide sample becomes stabilized as temperature increases. The sample exhibits a very good crystallinity upon calcination at 500 °C. Therefore, the sample of the Mo-W-O-500 complex was chosen for the comparison with MoO3 and WO3. The obtained XRD patterns of Mo-W-O, MoO3 and WO3 calcined at 500 °C are shown in Fig. 1 . The sharp and high intensity diffraction peaks observed in the XRD spectrum of Mo-W-O indicate that the material is of high crystallinity and purity. The result is in good agreement with what was observed for Mo0.6W0.4O3 reported previously by Yoon and Manthiram [33], indicating the formation of crystalline Mo0.6W0.4O3 with an orthorhombic structure (JPCDS 76-1280) of the space group Cmc21 (36). Furthermore, the diffraction peaks of the XRD pattern for the MoO3 sample can be readily indexed to be of orthorhombic phase (JPCDS 35-0609). No peaks of any other phases were detected, which suggests that the MoO3 complex is of high purity [25]. Likewise, the XRD pattern of the WO3 sample can be indexed to be monoclinic phase (JPCDS 72-1465) [37]. The results clearly indicate that the structure of the Mo0.6W0.4O3 complex differs unambiguously from the structures of MoO3 and WO3. In the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of the as-prepared Mo-W-O-T samples (Fig. S2), the typical type IV curves with H2 type hysteresis loops were observed at the relative pressure of 0.45–0.95, indicating the meso-porous structures in these samples. The pore size distributions of the Mo-W-O-T samples are shown in Fig. S3. All materials display a narrow distribution of mesopores within the diameter of 15 nm. The experimental data of BET surface areas, BJH desorption volume of pores and BJH desorption average pore width were listed in Table S2. The original Mo-W-O complex possesses the highest BET surface area as large as 188 m2/g. As the calcination temperature increases, both the BET surface areas and the BJH desorption volume of the pores are reduced, in contrast to the BJH desorption average pore width. The samples exhibit an amorphous structure at a slightly lower calcined temperature, which is attributed to the relatively loose and large pore structure. The higher calcination temperature, the better crystallinity the Mo-W-O compounds, consistent with the XRD patterns. Raman spectroscopy was utilized to determine the molecular structure of the prepared samples. The recorded spectra are shown in Fig. 2 . For the pure MoO3 complex, the Raman peaks observed at 994 cm−1 and 817 cm−1 are related to the MoO terminal group stretching modes [38] and the O-Mo-O stretching modes [39], respectively. The MoO3 complex exhibits the typical Raman scattering bands for α-MoO3 at 994, 817, 665, 377, 337, 290, 244, 157, 126, 114 cm−1 [40–42]. For the pure WO3 complex, the Raman bands at 806, 716, 326, 273, 134 and 71 cm−1 were also observed. The sharp peaks at 716 and 806 cm−1, 273 and 326 cm−1, 134 and 71 cm−1 are assigned to the O-W-O stretching mode, the W6+-O bending vibration, and the lattice modes, respectively [37,43]. These results are in good agreement with the Raman spectrum reported for a monoclinic WO3 [44]. Unlike the pure MoO3 and WO3 complexes, the as-prepared Mo-W oxide displays a significantly different Raman spectrum. Its spectral features differ radically from that of MoO3 and the main Raman peaks shift considerably from what is observed for WO3 with additional new features. The results suggest that the synthesized Mo0.6W0.4O3 complex is indeed a new phase crystal, not a physical mixture of MoO3 and WO3. The new phase of Mo-W-O distinctively different from that of MoO3 and WO3 can also be shown with additional evidence. The comparison of the XPS spectra among the samples of Mo-W-O, MoO3 and WO3 is shown in Fig. 3 . From Fig. 3(a), both the Mo 3d 5/2 and the Mo 3d 3/2 binding energies in the Mo-W-O complex are slightly shifted compared with that of MoO3. The W 4f 7/2 and the W 4f 5/2 binding energies in the Mo-W-O complex are markedly shifted compared with that of WO3. The binding energy shifts result from the intrinsic characteristic properties of the Mo-W-O complex, readily distinguishable from the features of MoO3 and WO3. Combined with the XRD and the Raman analyses, the sample of Mo-W-O prepared by the hydrothermal synthesis is clearly a new phase, possessing a structure different from the MoO3 and WO3 compounds synthesized with the same hydrothermal method. The SEM image of the product calcined at 500 °C is shown in Fig. 4 (a). It is apparent that the product is mainly composed of nanorods, which exhibit a wide range of widths from 100 to 600 nm. The lengths of the nanorods range from 0.1 µm to 1.5 µm. The TEM image shown in Fig. 4b indicates that the nanorods are well-ordered with four sharp corners at the upper terminals and rather flat tips. Furthermore, the inset in Fig. 4(c) shows a high resolution transition electron microscopy (HRTEM) image with the spacing of 0.384 nm, which is close to the distance of 0.3834 nm between (1 1 0) planes given from the standard JCPDS card, corresponding to the (1 1 0) orientation of the orthorhombic structure of Mo0.6W0.4O3. 3.2 Catalytic hydrogenation of cyclohexene Cyclohexene was used as a model substrate for hydrogenation to assess the catalytic performance. We first compared the catalytic activity of the as-prepared Mo-W-O materials calcined at various temperatures. Fig. S4 displays the conversion rates of the Mo-W-O-T samples for the reaction. The results show that full conversion of cyclohexane was achieved within 180 min by all the Mo-W-O-T samples. It was found from Fig. S2 that the BET surface area of the Mo-W-O-T samples decreases as the calcine temperature increases. Interestingly, the conversion rate was found not exactly positively correlating with the calcine temperature. This is likely due to the amorphous structure formed when the calcine temperature was not high enough to form a crystal structure. The sample of the Mo-W-O-500 complex was chosen to subsequent studies because of the good crystallinity upon calcination at 500 °C. The catalytic performances of the nanorod-structured Mo-W-O-500 catalyst was compared with several other catalysts, i.e. 0.1 wt% Pd/MoO3 [28], MoO3-500, WO3-500 and commercial 5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 (labeled as COM-Ru/Al2O3 in Fig. 5 ) at the same experimental conditions. The conversion of cyclohexene to cyclohexane as a function of time was recorded via an in-situ test of GCMS and the results are displayed in Fig. 5. Hydrogenation of cyclohexene was carried out at 150 °C and a H2 pressure of 3 MPa. 100% conversion was achieved within 180 min with both the sample Mo-W-O-500 catalyst and the commercial Ru/Al2O3 catalyst. Although both catalysts are active, we note that the activity of Mo-W-O-500 ramps up much faster than that of Ru/Al2O3, indicating rapid formation of hydrogen bronze that facilitates the hydrogenation reaction. Previous studies revealed that the mechanism of hydrogenation with bronze based catalysts differs significantly from the mechanism with transition metal catalysts with protonic hydrogen acting as the electrophilic hydrogenating species [16,17,28,45]. Surprisingly, the Mo-W-O-500 catalyst displays even better performance than MoO3 with 0.1 wt% of Pd, in which the precious metal serves as a promotor to dissociate H2 molecule to facilitate hydrogen spillover onto MoO3. It is likely that the uneven WO and MoO bonds give rise to a lower dissociation barrier for H2 and the nanorods of the complex provide more surface areas required for catalyzing the reaction. Detailed atomistic reaction processes will be investigated theoretically using density functional theory in our future study. The formation of cyclohexane was incomplete in the duration of our experiment with the pure MoO3 and WO3 catalysts due to the low catalytic activity. The kinetics of the 0.1 wt% Pd/Mo-100 catalyst was also found to be much slower [28], full conversion of cyclohexane was achieved nearly after 360 min. We next examined the cycle performance of the as-prepared Mo-W-O catalyst. Fig. 6 shows the conversion rate vs. reaction time for four cycles. The results revealed that hydrogenation was fully accomplished within 180 min for the first cycle and completed within 120 min for the subsequent three cycles. Clearly, the hydrogenation kinetics is accelerated sequentially with hydrogenation cycles. It is likely that the concentration of hydrogen bronze increases in the catalyst at each cycle. The hydrogenated Mo-W-O bronze material was also prepared via ex-situ hydrogenation of the Mo-W-O-500 catalyst and used to compare the catalytic performance with Mo-W-O-500 cycles. The conversion rate was also shown in Fig. 6. The catalytic activity of the ex-situ hydrogenated Mo-W-O bronze material was found to be comparable with that of the Mo-W-O-500 cycle 2 catalyst. Fig. 7 displays the XRD spectra of the Mo-W-O-500 complex before and after hydrogenation from cycle 1 to cycle 4. The XRD pattern, along with the Raman spectrum, of the as-prepared Mo-W-O-500 complex indicates that the structure of the material is a new phase Mo0.6W0.4O3. The main diffraction peaks were shifted significantly after the first cycle of hydrogenation, indicating that the component of the product was changed. Compared with the results published by Hibble et al. [29], the XRD pattern after the first cycle of hydrogenation can be indexed to the formation of hydrogen bronze. A marginal change of the intensity of the diffraction peaks is observed with the increase of the reaction cycles, suggesting that the hydrogen content of hydrogen molybdenum tungsten oxides bronze is enhanced slightly. From the search results of the available XRD PDF card library, the XRD pattern of the sample after 4 cycles of hydrogenation was indexed to the closest of the H0.15Mo0.5W0.5O3 (JCPDS 38-0142) complex, demonstrating the existence of hydrogen in the sample after catalytic hydrogenation. We speculate that hydrogen bronze needs time to be formed initially and the material then becomes capable of hydrogenating the unsaturated species. This explains why the first cycle of hydrogenation takes a longer time than the subsequent cycles. As the reaction proceeds further, a higher hydrogen content is incorporated in the complex, leading to accelerated kinetics. The results are consistent with the data of conversion rate vs. reaction time as shown in Fig. 6. It is expected that the kinetics will become steady as the material becomes fully saturated with bronze species. In order to analyze the properties of the as-prepared new crystal phase product, the material obtained from the last catalytic cycle was recycled for further study. The following characterizations were made for comparison of the Mo-W-O-500 complex before the catalytic hydrogenation and after 4 cycles of the reaction. Fig. 8 (a) shows the TPD spectra of the sample. Clearly, there are no apparent peaks in the sample before hydrogenation, indicating that during the temperature programmed desorption, no detectable substance was decomposed. However, two peaks appear in the sample after hydrogenation at the same experimental condition. These features clearly indicate that certain substances were produced in the high-temperature process. Based on the comparison of the TCD signal, the high-temperature TPD peaks can be attributed to the spillover of hydrogen upon hydrogenation [46]. Fig. 8(b) depicts the images of the sample before and after the hydrogenation. The color of the sample was changed from light yellow to dark blue upon the catalytic reaction. The sample color turns dark blue due to the reduction of the oxidation state of the metallic elements, which is in great agreement with Refs. [5,47]. Indeed, the valence states of Mo and W atoms in the Mo-W-O catalyst before and after reaction were probed by using a XPS analysis. Fig. 9 (a) shows that the Mo 3d band of the Mo-W-O complex before hydrogenation can be fitted with two curves peaked at 232.83 eV and 236 eV, respectively, assigned to Mo 3d 5/2 and Mo 3d3/2, in close agreement with the results reported previously [48]. The binding energies correspond to the +6 oxidation state of the Mo atoms [49,50]. Fig. 9(c) reveals that the Mo 3d band of the Mo-W-O catalyst after the catalytic hydrogenation can be fitted into a group of four peaks at 231.53 eV and 232.77 eV for Mo 3d 5/2, 234.73 eV and 235.97 eV for Mo 3d 3/2, respectively. These binding energies are attributed to the +5 and +6 valences of the Mo atoms [51]. Fig. 9(b) shows that the 4f and 5p bands of W in the Mo-W-O catalyst before hydrogenation can be fitted with three curves with peaks located at 35.68 eV, 37.85 eV and 41.6 eV, which are assigned to W 4f 7/2, W 4f 5/2 and W 5p 3/2, respectively, indicating that the +6 oxidation state of W atoms. Fig. 9(d) demonstrates that the W 4f and 5p bands of the Mo-W-O complex upon catalytic hydrogenation can be fitted into a group of five curves peaked at 35.04 eV and 35.76 eV (corresponding to W 4f 7/2), 37.19 eV and 37.91 eV (corresponding to W 4f 5/2), 41.6 eV (corresponding to 5p 3/2), respectively. All the binding energies are assigned to the +6 oxidation state of the W atoms [52-55], except for the peak at 35.04 eV, which is associated with the +5 oxidation state of the W atoms. Compared with the peak area reduction from the +6 oxidation state to the +5 oxidation state for both Mo and W atoms, we found that it is more significant for Mo than for W, indicating that Mo in its +6 oxidation state is more reducible than W in the same state, which is as expected and consistent with what was reported previously [8]. 4 Summary In the present study, we reported a facile hydrothermal synthesis of nanorod-structured molybdenum-tungsten oxide and demonstrated the material may serve as an efficient catalyst for olefin hydrogenation. The structure of the prepared compound was confirmed via a series of analytic characterizations to be of a new crystalline phase (Mo0.6W0.4O3), rather than a simple mixture of MoO3 and WO3 complexes. Using hydrogenation of cyclohexene as a model system, we found that the Mo-W-O complex exhibits superior catalytic performance for hydrogenation. 100% conversion of cyclohexene was achieved in 3 h. Remarkably, the catalyst was found to be kinetically more active than the frequently used commercial catalyst, 5 wt% Ru/Al2O3. Furthermore, it was shown that the Mo-W-O complex absent of precious metals performs even better than the 0.1 wt% Pd/MoO3 catalyst in catalyzing the reaction. We speculate that oxygen vacancies in the oxide lattice are responsible for the dissociation of HH bond, which is essential for hydrogenation. Similar phenomenon with MoO3 and WO3 as catalysts in the absence of transition metals has been observed before but bronze formation took a significantly longer time with much slower hydrogenation kinetics [56–58]. In comparison, the pure MoO3 and WO3 complexes synthesized with the same method display low catalytic activity. It was found that the formation of hydrogen bronze in the HxMo0.6W0.4O3 complex is largely responsible for the enhanced catalytic performance and the catalytic activity is positively correlated with the hydrogen content. Our results demonstrate that the nanorod-structured molybdenum-tungsten oxide may be a strong contender for serving as efficient hydrogenation catalyst alternative to precious metal catalysts. coredata.dc:description: We report a facile hydrothermal synthesis of nanorod-structured molybdenum-tungsten oxides as an efficient catalyst for olefin hydrogenation. The catalytic activity was demonstrated through hydrogenation of cyclohexene used as a model system. The as-prepared material was confirmed as a new phase (Mo0.6W0.4O3) via a series of characterizations, instead of a simple mixture of MoO3 and WO3. The Mo0.6W0.4O3 catalyst displays excellent catalytic activity with 100% conversion of cyclohexene in 3 h, which is much higher than that of pure MoO3 and pure WO3 synthesized with the same method. It was found that hydrogen bronze (HxMo0.6W0.4O3) was formed during the hydrogenation process, and the catalytic performance was positively correlated with the hydrogen content. The obtained nanorod-structured Mo0.6W0.4O3 without loading any noble metal exhibits much higher catalytic activity than a Pd/MoO3 catalyst. The results demonstrate that the nanorod-structured molybdenum-tungsten oxide may be a strong contender for serving as an efficient hydrogenation catalyst alternative to precious metals.
coredata.dc:title: Facile hydrothermal synthesis of nanorod-structured Mo0.6W0.4O3 catalyst for olefin hydrogenation with high activity
